message.entry: Select a hardware board to set-up

The hardware setup configures the hardware to run a custom image of Raspbian Linux operating system on the hardware. The custom image is composed of all the required software packages for the OS to be compatible with MATLAB and Simulink
Raspberry Pi B has Broadcom BCM2835 chip and an ARMv6 single core processor. It uses SD card storage with 26 GPIO pins and 2 USB ports.
Raspberry Pi Zero W has Broadcom BCM2835 chip and an ARMv6 single core processor. It uses MicroSD card storage with 40 GPIO pins and 2 micro USB ports.
Raspberry Pi B+ has a Broadcom BCM2835 chip and an ARMv6 single core processor. It uses MicroSD card storage with 40 GPIO pins and 4 USB ports.
Raspberry Pi 2.0 B has a Broadcom BCM2836 chip and an ARMv7 quad core processor. It uses MicroSD card storage with 40 GPIO pins and 4 USB ports.
Raspberry Pi 3.0 B has a Broadcom BCM2837 chip and an ARM Cortex A-53 quad core processor. It uses MicroSD card storage with 40 GPIO pins and 4 USB ports.
Raspberry Pi 3.0 B+ has a Broadcom BCM2837 chip and an ARM Cortex A-53 quad core processor. It uses MicroSD card storage with 40 GPIO pins and 4 USB ports.

Make sure that the Raspberry Pi is connected to your host computer using a local area network (LAN) or home network similar to the ones that the installer displays, as shown in the images. Then, click Next.
This option in Select Network Configuration applies dynamic network settings provided by a DHCP service on the network.
Make sure that the Raspberry Pi is connected to your host computer using a direct connection similar to the one that the installer displays, as shown in the image. Then, click Next.
This option in Select Network Configuration applies static network settings based upon the network settings of the host computer.
To manually configure the network settings, select this option and connect Raspberry Pi to your host computer over the network. Then, click Next.
This option in Select Network Configuration allows you to manually enter network settings.
Make sure that the Raspberry Pi is in the vicinity of the wireless access point you want to connect. Then, click Next.
This option in Select Network Configuration allows you to connect to a wireless network.
USB Gadget what to consider. Then, click Next.
Connect to LAN or home network
If multiple Raspberry Pi boards are connected to same network, manually edit the host name to make it unique.

The HostName parameter displays the host name that is assigned to the Raspberry Pi.



The selected IP assignment applies dynamic network settings provided by a DHCP service on the network.

The HostName parameter displays the host name that is assigned to the Raspberry Pi.



Manual IP assignment allows to edit the IP address, Network mask, and Default gateway settings. Also see Guidelines for Entering Static IP Settings.

The set up process for Raspberry Pi board consists of copying a supported Raspbian Linux firmware image onto a memory card and booting the Raspberry Pi with this memory card.
Checklist
  • Raspberry Pi
  • SD Card (4GB or larger)
  • 5V micro USB power supply
  • Ethernet Cable
Yes, Connect to a wireless network
This will skip the wireless configuration step. You can access the Raspberry Pi over USB using the IP address 192.168.9.2
Raspberry Pi is directly connected to the host computer via USB/Ethernet Gadget.
This will allow you to connect Raspberry Pi to a wireless network.
Ensure that Raspberry Pi is in the vicinity of the wireless network before clicking the Scan button.

Set the security options for the selected wireless network.



The selected IP assignment applies dynamic network settings provided by a DHCP service on the network.

Set the security options for the selected wireless network.



Manual IP assignment allows to edit the IP address, Network mask, and Default gateway settings. Also see Guidelines for Entering Static IP Settings.
Ensure that you have selected the correct security option for the wireless network to be connected.
Do you want to connect to a wireless network?
Connect the Raspberry Pi using the following instructions:
1. Remove the memory card from the host computer and insert into the Raspberry Pi.
1. Unmount and remove the memory card from the host computer and insert into the Raspberry Pi.
2. Connect an Ethernet cable to the Raspberry Pi. Connect the other end of the Ethernet cable to your LAN or HOME network.
2. Connect an Ethernet cable to the Raspberry Pi Connect the other end of the Ethernet cable directly to the host computer.
2. Connect an Ethernet cable to the Raspberry Pi Connect the other end of the Ethernet cable to your network.
2. Make sure Raspberry Pi is in the vicinity of the wireless router.
2. Connect the USB WiFi dongle and make sure Raspberry Pi is in the vicinity of the wireless router.
3. Connect a 5V micro USB power supply to the Raspberry Pi. The power supply should be rated for at least 700 mA.
2. Connect Raspberry Pi to your host computer via micro USB cable. Please make sure that you have connected to the data USB port as shown below.
Make sure that the 'PWR' LED is solid red and the {0} LED indicating SD card activity, starts blinking. Then, click Next.
Make sure that the green 'ACT' LED indicating SD card activity starts blinking. Then, click Next.
You may connect optional peripherals such as a monitor, keyboard, etc. at this time.
Detecting Raspberry Pi terminated, please check the connection and try again.
Could not detect the Raspberry Pi in allotted time. Try using 'Test Connection' option in the next screen.
To write firmware to the SD card {0}, click 'Write'.

The write operation may take several minutes.



After first successful 'write firmware to SD card' operation, any changes made to the Network Settings do not effect the firmware already written on the SD card. So, the need for writing the firmware again is not required.

Write Firmware successful. Click Next to continue.



Writing firmware to SD card can be skipped, if at least once the write operation was successful. After successful write, even if changes are made in Network Settings screen, writing firmware again can be skipped.
If changes are made to the network configuration in the future, writing firmware to SD card can be skipped.
Do not take out inserted SD Card, after successful writing of firmware. Additional configuration files are written to SD card in the next step, click Next.
Error writing the firmware to the SD card: {0}
Error creating SD card writer script
All data in the memory card will be erased during firmware write!
Error writing firmware to the memory card: {0}

Unable to write the firmware to the SD card. Make sure the SD card is not in use. Try reinserting and unmounting the SD card. Repeat the Write Firmware process. If the error still persists then format the SD card and reinsert.
Not able to detect any SD card with FAT-32 partition. Insert an SD card (>= 4GB) with at least one FAT-32 partition on the host computer.
Not able to detect any SD card with FAT-32 partition. Insert an SD card (>= 4GB) with at least one FAT-32 partition on the host computer.\nRestart the set-up process.
Not able to detect the memory card.\nKeep the memory card inserted to write firmware.
Not able to detect the memory card.\nKeep the memory card inserted to write additional configuration files.
Insert a 4 GB or larger {0} memory card into a memory card reader on the host computer.\n\nSelect the drive that corresponds to the memory card reader:
Insert a 4 GB or larger {0} memory card into a memory card reader on the host computer.\n\nSelect the Volume that corresponds to the memory card reader:
If you do not find the memory card reader in the list of drives, reinsert the memory card fully. Then, click Refresh.
Navigating to next screen is allowed only when inserted SD card's file system is selected.
Invalid host name. Host name must be composed of ASCII letters ('a-z', 'A-Z'), the digits ('0-9'),\nand the hyphen ('-') and must be between 1 and 63 characters long.
{0} is not a valid IP address.

If you want to login to the Raspberry Pi in the future, the host name, IP address, user name, and password are displayed in the screen.
Click Test Connection to verify the SSH connection to the Raspberry Pi.
USB interface ip address, 192.168.9.2 will be used to verify the connection.
1. Your Raspberry Pi will speak its IP address through the analog audio connector when it boots.
2. You can configure your Raspberry Pi to automatically send an e-mail when IP address changes.
If the Test Connection succeeds, click Next to finish the set-up process.
If the Test Connection FAILS, click Back and follow the instructions again or try switching to another Network Setting.
If the Test Connection FAILS, click Back and follow the instructions again or try switching to another Network Setting.
Test connection terminated, please try again.
The hardware set-up process for Raspberry Pi is complete.
MATLAB and Simulink support package for Raspberry Pi require a customized version of Raspbian Linux Operating System (OS) running on the hardware.
Setup hardware with MathWorks Raspbian image
Customize the existing operating system running on my hardware

The option uses the Raspbian image provided by MathWorks to setup the hardware. MathWorks Raspbian Linux image is composed of default Raspbian Stretch Lite image with all the required libraries and packages for the image to be compatible with MATLAB and Simulink
The option validates and installs all the missing Linux packages and libraries required to make the Raspbian OS compatible with MATLAB and Simulink.

To setup the hardware, the hardware setup app copies a supported Raspbian Linux firmware image to a memory card, and then boots the hardware with this memory card..

Checklist:
  • Raspberry Pi Board
  • SD Card (4GB or larger)
  • 5V micro USB power supply
  • Ethernet cable or Wireless access point

To setup the hardware, the hardware setup app copies a supported Raspbian Linux firmware image to a memory card, and then boots the hardware with this memory card..

Checklist:
  • Raspberry Pi Board
  • SD Card (4GB or larger)
  • 5V micro USB power supply

To update the operating system, installation of new software packages and libraries is required. Ensure that the hardware has internet acces
We recommend you take a backup of the operating system running on your hardware before proceeding with the customization.

Before connecting to the hardware, ensure that the hardware:
  • Is powered ON
  • Is running a valid Raspbian operating system image and is bootable
  • Can be connected using a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.
  • Has Internet access


If the Test connection succeeds click Next to proceed, else verify the login credentials and re-test.
The Operating System (OS) customization process requires a network connection to the hardware.\nSpecify the login details of the hardware.
Establishing SSH connection with hardware at {0} ...
Establishing SSH connection with hardware failed

Before connecting to the hardware, ensure that the hardware:
  • Is powered ON
  • Is running a valid Raspbian operating system image and is bootable
  • Can be connected using a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.
  • Has Internet access


If the Test connection FAILS with the Pinging hardware failed message,verify the Device address and re-test.

Before connecting to the hardware, ensure that the hardware:
  • Is powered ON
  • Is running a valid Raspbian operating system image and is bootable
  • Can be connected using a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.
  • Has Internet access


If the Test connection FAILS with the Establishing SSH connection with hardware failed message, verify login credentials and ensure that SSH is enabled on the hardware, else click Next to proceed.

Before connecting to the hardware, ensure that the hardware:
  • Is powered ON
  • Is running a valid Raspbian operating system image and is bootable
  • Can be connected using a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.
  • Has Internet access


If the Test connection FAILS with the Verifying Sudo user privilege failed message,verify that the username provided has sudoer access and password less sudo is enabled and re-test. For more information on enabling sudo privilege click here

Before connecting to the hardware, ensure that the hardware:
  • Is powered ON
  • Is running a valid Raspbian operating system image and is bootable
  • Can be connected using a Secure Shell (SSH) terminal.
  • Has Internet access


If the Test connection FAILS with the Verifying Internet access failed message,verify that the hardware has Internet access and re-test.
The listed software packages and libraries will be validated and installed on your hardware.
Installation of software packages and libraries on the Raspberry Pi OS requires Internet access. Ensure that the hardware has internet access.
Sensors and Actuators can be interfaced to various peripherals available on Raspberry Pi.\nSet the state of each peripheral module

The current state of the peripheral modules on Raspberry Pi are being displayed. Enable or Disable the required peripheral modules and click Next. The changes made will take effect after the Raspberry Pi reboots.
Install the required packages and libraries on the Raspbian Operating System (OS) running on the hardware.

This task will modify the OS by installing new software packages and libraries that are missing.
We recommend that you perform a backup of the operating system running on your hardware before proceeding with the installation.
.
The changes applied during the customization process of the operating system require a reboot of Raspberry Pi to take effect.
This option will initiate a reboot of the Raspberry Pi. Click Next to reboot Raspberry Pi and complete the Hardware Setup.

Click Next to complete Hardware Setup.
Remember to reboot Raspberry Pi before using it with MATLAB and Simulink.
